choices.text: Chronic HepB with HBe Ag negative
Chronic HepB with HBe Ag positive

questions.text: A young man was diagnosed with Hepatitis B a year ago, presenting with jaundice and elevated HBsAg levels at the time. On follow-up, his liver enzyme levels are now within the normal range. His current serologic profile is shown in the image provided. Based on the current findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's persistent HBsAg positivity for over a year, along with anti-HBs negativity, HBeAg positivity, and anti-HBc IgG positivity, confirms chronic Hepatitis B with active viral replication.




Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/354997816_Hepatitis_B_Vaccines

choices.text: Medial rectus is the first muscle to be involved.
The muscles and connective tissue around the eye share similar antigen with diseased organ

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with tremors and weight loss. Her ophthalmic examination shows the following findings. Identify the true statement regarding the following condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a middle-aged female presenting with tremors, weight loss, and exophthalmos, as seen in the provided image, is consistent with Graves' ophthalmopathy. In this condition, the muscles and connective tissue around the eye are targeted by autoimmune mechanisms due to shared antigens with the thyroid.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK549889/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15838447/#

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with fatigue and imbalance 3 months after undergoing ileal resection due to trauma. He also reports numbness in his feet and difficulty walking in the dark.Which of the following will not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fatigue following ileal resection points towards macrocytic anemia, most likely due to vitamin B12 deficiency, which is commonly seen after ileal resection. This is not associated with microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is typically caused by iron deficiency.

Vitamin B12 Deficiency (Cobalamin): A water-soluble vitamin found in animal products (red meat, dairy, eggs). Requires intrinsic factor from gastric parietal cells for absorption in the terminal ileum.

Etiology:

  • Autoimmune: Pernicious anemia (anti-intrinsic factor antibodies inhibit B12 absorption).
  • Malabsorption: Ileal damage (Crohn's disease, ileal resection), gastric bypass.
  • Dietary: Strict vegan diets.
  • Toxins: Nitrous oxide exposure.

B12 is a cofactor for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, converting methylmalonyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA. Deficiency → ↑ methylmalonic acid → myelin damage → subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord (SCDSC).

Clinical Features:

  • Neurologic: Proprioception loss, ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, dementia, positive Romberg.
  • Others: Fatigue, pallor, glossitis, diarrhea, neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Investigations:

  • CBC: Macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100), hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • Serum B12: <200 pg/mL = deficient; 200-300 = borderline.
  • MMA & Homocysteine: Both elevated (MMA normal in folate deficiency).

Treatment:

  • Dietary deficiency: Oral B12.
  • Malabsorption/pernicious anemia: Parenteral B12.
  • Parenteral protocol: 1000 mcg IM weekly × 4 weeks, then monthly.

Cyto-nuclear dys-synchrony (Option A) is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency.

Romberg's sign positive (Option C): This is associated with sensory ataxia, which can result from vitamin B12 deficiency due to the involvement of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, leading to proprioceptive deficits. It is a potential sign in a patient with B12 deficiency.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441923/

choices.text: Ankle clonus in the right foot
Proprioception lost in the left leg
Pain and temperature were lost in the right leg

questions.text: A patient suffered from RTA. After a few days, he had exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and knee jerk. What other findings would be seen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with a history of a right-sided injury (likely a spinal cord injury) resulting in an exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and knee jerk suggests an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.

Ankle clonus is a common finding in UMN lesions and would likely be seen in the right foot in this case.

Clonus: Refers to rhythmic, involuntary muscle contractions, typically occurring at 5-7 Hz, most commonly at the ankle and patella, caused by rapidly stretching and holding a muscle joint at a constant length, and is commonly seen in upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions.


Proprioception lost in left leg (Option B): Loss of proprioception suggests damage to the dorsal column, which carries ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense. Since the patient exhibits right-sided UMN signs, proprioception loss would also be expected on the right side, making this option incorrect.

Pain and temperature was lost in the right leg (Option C): Pain and temperature sensations are carried by the spinothalamic tract, which decussates (crosses) at the spinal level. Therefore, a right-sided lesion would typically cause left-sided pain and temperature loss, making this option incorrect.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537305/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/lower-motor-neuron-lesion https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541082/#

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with lethargy and tiredness. On examination, he has perioral hyperpigmentation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg and his heart rate is 110 beats/minute. Laboratory investigations revealed Na+ of 125mEq/L and K+ of 5.5mEq/L. What is the most appropriate treatment given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with lethargy, tiredness, perioral hyperpigmentation, hypotension, along with laboratory findings of hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, points towards a diagnosis of Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency). The most appropriate treatment for this patient is a combination of hydrocortisone + fludrocortisone, as it provides the necessary glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement.

ACTH (Option A): ACTH stimulation test is used to diagnose Addison's disease, but it is not a treatment. ACTH would stimulate the adrenal glands to release cortisol, which is not effective in Addison's disease since the adrenal glands are damaged or nonfunctional.

Dexamethasone (Option C) is a glucocorticoid that lacks mineralocorticoid activity. Addison's disease requires both glucocorticoid (for cortisol replacement) and mineralocorticoid (for sodium and fluid balance), which dexamethasone alone cannot provide.

Saline infusion (Option D): Saline infusion is useful in managing dehydration and hypotension, but it does not address the underlying hormonal deficiency in Addison's disease. The patient needs corticosteroid replacement (both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid), not just fluid resuscitation.

questions.text:
Match the following ECG waves with the conditions:

a) Atrial flutter
b) Atrial fibrillation
c) Ventricular tachycardia
d) Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia

1.
2.
3.
4.
questions.solution:
1. Atrial Flutter: A standard PR interval is absent due to continuous, rapid flutter waves instead of distinct P waves. These flutter waves occur at regular rhythm and at a rate of 250-350 beats per minute, creating a "sawtooth" ECG pattern. The AV node conducts only some impulses (e.g., 2:1 or 4:1), leading to an organized ventricular response but without a conventional PR interval.
  2. Atrial Fibrillation: ECG shows irregularly irregular rhythm but normal QRS complexes, absent P waves, and a baseline with irregular fibrillation waves; the ventricular rate is fast at onset (120-160 beats/min) but may be slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue.
  3. Ventricular Tachycardia: ECG findings for monomorphic VT include wide QRS complexes (>120 ms), a regular rhythm, and consistent morphology across leads. The QRS axis may vary depending on the site of origin, such as showing left bundle branch block (LBBB) or right bundle branch block (RBBB)-like morphology. For polymorphic VT, the ECG shows continuously changing QRS morphology, often associated with prolonged QT intervals, as seen in Torsades de Pointes.
  4. Paroxysmal Ventricular Tachycardia: ECG shows regular, narrow-complex tachycardia with a QRS duration of less than 120 ms and a reduced R-R interval. The heart rate ranges between 150-250 beats per minute, and the P waves are often not visible or are buried in the T waves.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with fatigue and hemoptysis. His current hemoglobin is 8g/dL (previous hemoglobin one week ago was 12g/dL). His bronchoalveolar lavage is reddish, and his serum creatinine was 1.7mg/dL. He is diagnosed with ANCA-positive glomerulonephritis. Biopsy of the kidney revealed pauci-immune deposits and the absence of granulomas. Which of the following conditions is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fatigue, hemoptysis, ANCA-positive glomerulonephritis, elevated serum creatinine (pulmonary-renal syndrome), and no granulomas on biopsy points towards the diagnosis of Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA).

SLE (Option C) (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus) is an autoimmune disorder that affects multiple organs and is characterized by a wide range of autoantibodies, especially antinuclear antibodies (ANA). The renal involvement in SLE typically results from immune complex deposition rather than pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, and the clinical features often include a characteristic butterfly rash, photosensitivity, and systemic symptoms that are not present in this patient.

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (Option D) (HSP) primarily affects children and is characterized by leukocytoclastic vasculitis and IgA deposition, with typical manifestations such as palpable purpura, arthritis, gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, diarrhea), and renal involvement (e.g., hematuria, proteinuria). Unlike in Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA), HSP does not typically present with ANCA positivity or pulmonary involvement such as hemoptysis, and the renal pathology involves IgA rather than pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old presented with fever, chills & cough with sputum. Blood pressure was measured to be 150/88mmhg, pulse rate 110bpm and respiratory rate - 18, spo2 - 88% at room air. An X-ray was done and shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, chills, productive cough, and lobar consolidation on chest X-ray points towards the diagnosis of Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP).

Community-Acquired Pneumonia:

  • Etiology:
    • Common bacterial pathogens: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus.
    • Atypical organisms: Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, Legionella species, and respiratory viruses such as influenza.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Symptoms: Fever, cough (productive or nonproductive), dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea).
    • Physical signs: Increased respiratory rate, use of accessory muscles, tactile fremitus changes, dull percussion, crackles, and bronchial breath sounds.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical Diagnosis: Diagnosis of CAP requires a history of symptoms (fever, cough, dyspnea) and chest radiography showing new infiltrates.
    • Radiography: Chest X-ray or CT is used to diagnose CAP and may reveal signs like cavitation or multilobar involvement.
    • Laboratory Diagnosis: Gram stain and culture of sputum, blood cultures, urine antigen tests, PCR, serology, and biomarkers like C-reactive protein and procalcitonin help identify the pathogen.
  • CURB-65 Criteria:
    • Criteria used for assessing the severity of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).
    • The criteria is based on five factors:
      1. Confusion
      2. Urea level >7 mmol/L
      3. Respiratory rate >30 breaths/min
      4. Blood pressure: systolic BP <90 mm Hg or diastolic BP <60 mm Hg
      5. Age: 65 years or older
  • Each factor contributes 1 point, leading to a score range from 0 to 5.
    • Score 0: Treated as an outpatient.
    • Score 1 or 2: Requires hospitalization.
    • Score ≥ 3: Requires ICU admission.

Tubercular pleural effusion (Option A): While pleural effusion can present with fever, dyspnea, and pleuritic pain, it typically manifests with dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds on examination. Chest X-ray usually shows a blunted costophrenic angle or a meniscus sign rather than lobar consolidation, which is characteristic of pneumonia.

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option C) (CWP) is an occupational disease caused by chronic exposure to coal dust. It typically presents with small opacities in the upper lobes of the lungs, not lobar consolidation.

Silicosis (Option D) is caused by exposure to silica dust. Silicosis presents with small rounded opacities in the upper lobes and may show eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes on imaging. The pattern on high-resolution CT (HRCT) is typically "crazy paving," not lobar consolidation.

questions.text:
Which of the following is most likely based on the lab values given?

Blood pH: 7.3
Na+: 134 mEq/L
K+: 2.8 mEq/L
Cl-: 113 mEq/L
HCO₃⁻: 12 mEq/L
BUN: 3 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
Urinary pH: 9.4
questions.solution:
The lab values, including a blood pH of 7.3, low bicarbonate, high urinary pH (9.4), and hypokalemia, are consistent with Type I renal tubular acidosis, characterized by impaired hydrogen ion secretion in the distal tubule.


High anion gap metabolic acidosis (Option D) (HAGMA) is characterized by an increased anion gap due to the accumulation of unmeasured anions. In this case, the calculated anion gap is normal (AG = 9), which rules out HAGMA. Since there is no evidence of unmeasured anions causing the acidosis, HAGMA is not the correct diagnosis.

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Characteristics-of-the-types-of-renal-tubular-acidosis_tbl5_328347660

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Diagnostic-criteria-for-renal-tubular-acidosis_tbl4_267744743

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519044/#

choices.text: Cardioversion in a hemodynamically unstable patient
Beta blockers are to be given for rate control if the patient is intolerant to calcium channel blockers
IV digoxin for ventricular rate control

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents with palpitation, dyspnea, bilateral basal crackles and irregularly irregular pulse. Which of the following management methods is least useful?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient presents with palpitations, dyspnea, bilateral basal crackles, and irregular RR intervals with absent P waves on ECG, suggesting acute decompensated heart failure with atrial fibrillation. In these patients, beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers are not used due to their negative inotropic effects, which can decrease cardiac output, lower blood pressure, and increase left ventricular pressure, potentially worsening heart failure.


Cardioversion in a hemodynamically unstable patient (Option A): Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation (AF). In this case, since the patient is presenting with dyspnea, bilateral basal crackles, and irregular pulse, hemodynamic instability can occur due to acute decompensated heart failure and AF, making cardioversion an appropriate and essential treatment option.

Direct oral anticoagulants (Option B) (DOACs): Atrial fibrillation (AF) increases the risk of thrombus formation, particularly in the left atrium, leading to stroke or other thromboembolic events. Therefore, anticoagulation is crucial in managing AF, and DOACs are the preferred choice for most patients. This makes DOACs an important part of the management for this patient with AF.

Intravenous digoxin for ventricular rate control (Option D): Intravenous digoxin can be used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, especially in patients with heart failure or when other medications like beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers are contraindicated or not tolerated. While digoxin may not be the first-line therapy, it can be beneficial in acute settings, especially in patients with heart failure making IV digoxin an appropriate choice for this patient with acute decompensated heart failure and AF.

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the murmur depicted in the image below.
questions.solution: The given image shows a pansystolic murmur, which is characteristic of mitral regurgitation (MR). This occurs when the mitral valve does not close completely during systole, causing a backflow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium. It is typically heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) or the reverse urea effect.

Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS) is an acute neurological complication, often seen in patients undergoing their first hemodialysis session. It results from the rapid removal of urea and solutes, creating an osmotic gradient between the blood and brain interstitial fluid. This gradient causes water to shift into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema.

Features:

Symptoms: Headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, restlessness, confusion, muscle cramps, tremors, and in severe cases, seizures or coma.

Risk Factors: First hemodialysis session, high blood urea nitrogen (BUN >175 mg/dL), children, elderly, rapid dialysis, and pre-existing neurological conditions.

Management:

  • Modify dialysis parameters to reduce urea removal rates.
  • Administer osmotic agents like mannitol to reduce cerebral edema.
  • Provide supportive care for symptoms.

Prevention:

  • Initiate dialysis at a slower rate with shorter sessions.
  • Adjust dialysate composition, particularly sodium levels.
  • Avoid aggressive uremia correction, especially in high-risk patients.

Bumetanide (Option A): Bumetanide is a loop diuretic used to treat conditions like fluid overload or edema, but it is not indicated for the management of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. It works by inhibiting sodium and chloride reabsorption in the kidney, and does not address the osmotic shifts causing cerebral edema in DDS.

Ethacrynic acid (Option B): Ethacrynic acid is another loop diuretic that can be used in conditions like edema, but it is not the first choice for treating DDS. It does not counteract the osmotic gradient responsible for cerebral edema during dialysis.

Nesiritide (Option C): Nesiritide is a recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide, used to treat acute decompensated heart failure. It does not address the underlying pathophysiology of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome, which involves osmotic shifts causing cerebral edema.

Reference: NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of thyroid storm (or thyroid crisis), a life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. The patient's symptoms, including severe restlessness, palpitations, tremors, tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and a swollen neck, are consistent with thyroid storm. The immediate priority is to control the heart rate due to the atrial fibrillation and high risk of complications such as heart failure.

In thyroid storm, beta-blockers like propranolol or esmolol are often used for rate control; however, they are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchospasm (Options B and C ruled out).

Instead, diltiazem, a calcium channel blocker, is the preferred option for rate control in this patient, as it does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects of beta-blockers.


Propylthiouracil (PTU) (Option D): Propylthiouracil is used to inhibit the synthesis of thyroid hormones in thyroid storm and is the drug of choice for the management of thyroid storm. However, it should be given only after the rate of atrial fibrillation is controlled, as the primary goal in the acute setting is to stabilize the patient and manage the arrhythmia.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1681414/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448095/

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions that appear as umbilicated papules and nodules predominantly on the face, trunk, and upper extremities. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a HIV-positive patient with persistent cough, weight loss, skin lesions (umbilicated papules and nodules), and bilateral nodular infiltrates on chest x-ray, along with a low CD4 count, suggests a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis

A systemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus endemic in regions like the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, Central/South America, and Africa.

Pathophysiology:

  • Acquired by inhaling fungal microconidia from contaminated soil (bird/bat droppings).
  • Yeast forms multiply in macrophages, spreading through lymphatics and bloodstream.
  • Immunocompromised hosts (e.g., HIV/AIDS, CD4+ <200/μL) are at higher risk of dissemination.

Clinical Features:

Asymptomatic: Common in immunocompetent individuals.

Acute Pulmonary: Fever, cough, chest pain, flu-like symptoms.

Chronic Pulmonary: Associated with COPD, presenting with cough, weight loss, and cavitary lung lesions.

Progressive Disseminated Histoplasmosis (PDH):

  • Systemic: Fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia.
  • Lungs: Diffuse interstitial or reticulonodular infiltrates.
  • Skin: Papules, plaques, or ulcers (~10% cases).

Diagnosis:

  • Antigen detection: Urine, serum, or BAL fluid.
  • Culture: Blood, bone marrow, or BAL fluid (gold standard, slow).
  • Histopathology: Yeast forms in macrophages (PAS/GMS stains).
  • Imaging: Chest X-ray or CT shows infiltrates or cavitary lesions.

Treatment:

Mild to Moderate: Itraconazole for 6-12 months.

Severe/PDH: Liposomal amphotericin B (induction) followed by itraconazole (maintenance for ≥12 months).

Chronic Pulmonary: Itraconazole for 12-24 months.

HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis (Option B): Cryptococcosis is commonly associated with meningeal involvement in immunocompromised patients. This patient's symptoms (including the skin lesions and lung involvement) do not suggest cryptococcosis, especially as there are no signs of meningitis.

HIV with molluscum contagiosum (Option C): Molluscum contagiosum is a skin infection caused by a poxvirus, typically characterized by umbilicated papules on the skin. While this patient does have skin lesions, the lung involvement and the bilateral nodular infiltrates on the chest x-ray point to a systemic fungal infection rather than a localized skin condition.

HIV with tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculosis would typically present with symptoms like cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. However, the patient's negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis and absence of granulomas on imaging make tuberculosis less likely.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3687172/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3969680/

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN-type lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described in this case-sensory loss, weakness of limbs, angular stomatitis, loss of proprioception and vibration sensation, UMN-type weakness, and absent ankle reflexes-are highly suggestive of subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD), which is a condition caused by vitamin B12 deficiency.

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord (SACD)

Neurological disorder due to vitamin B12 deficiency, causing demyelination of the posterior columns and lateral corticospinal tracts.

Etiology

Vitamin B12 Deficiency:

  • Pernicious anemia.
  • Gastrectomy or ileal resection.
  • Diphyllobothrium latum infestation.
  • Long-term use of metformin or PPIs.

Affected Areas

  • Posterior columns: Loss of proprioception and vibration sense.
  • Lateral corticospinal tracts: Spasticity and UMN-type weakness.

Clinical Features

Sensory Symptoms:

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration sense: Begins in lower limbs, may progress to upper limbs.
  • Sensory ataxia: Positive Romberg's test (difficulty standing with eyes closed).
  • Paresthesia: Tingling or numbness in extremities, typically in a glove-and-stocking distribution.

Motor Symptoms:

  • Upper motor neuron signs: Weakness, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
  • Spastic weakness: Due to lateral corticospinal tract involvement.
  • Absent ankle reflex: A key finding, coexisting with UMN signs due to concurrent peripheral neuropathy.

Signs:

  • Lhermitte's Sign: Electric shock-like sensation down the spine on neck flexion.
  • Angular stomatitis
  • Optic neuropathy

Non-neurological Features:

Megaloblastic anemia: fatigue, pallor, glossitis, and jaundice.

Psychiatric Symptoms:

  • Irritability, dementia, psychosis.
  • Depression and memory loss.

Treatment

  • Vitamin B12 Replacement:
    • IM cyanocobalamin or hydroxocobalamin.
    • Oral B12 for maintenance.
  • Address underlying causes (e.g., anemia, parasitic infestation).

Extradural cord compression (Option A), caused by a space-occupying lesion (e.g., tumor or abscess), typically presents with localized back pain, radicular symptoms, and bladder/bowel dysfunction. It typically causes asymmetric neurological deficits, unlike the symmetrical loss of proprioception, vibration, and UMN signs seen in subacute combined degeneration. Additionally, it does not cause angular stomatitis, which is indicative of vitamin B12 deficiency

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) (Option B) primarily affects lower motor neurons and upper motor neurons. It presents with fasciculations, muscle cramps, muscle weakness, and atrophy, as well as bulbar palsy symptoms (dysarthria, dysphagia). Absence of sensory loss is a key differentiator here, as ALS does not typically affect sensory pathways.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) (Option C): MS is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system, affecting both white matter in the brain and spinal cord. It commonly presents with symptoms like paresthesia, optical neuritis, weakness, and gait disturbances. Lhermitte's sign (pain down the back with neck flexion) and Uhthoff's sign (worsening of symptoms with heat) are classic, but the sensory loss and angular stomatitis here point more toward vitamin B12 deficiency rather than MS.

questions.text: The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) specimen of a patient is shown below, along with microscopy. The report shows mononuclear cytosis, elevated proteins, and low sugars. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with CSF findings of mononuclear cytosis, elevated proteins, low sugars, and the characteristic cobweb-like clot, strongly suggests tuberculous meningitis (TBM).

Features of Tuberculous Meningitis (TBM):

  • Etiology: Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, spreading hematogenously or via rupture of subependymal tubercles into the subarachnoid space.
  • Presentation: Subacute infection with fever, headache, neck stiffness, and cranial nerve palsies (commonly ocular nerves due to basal meningeal involvement).
  • Complications: Hydrocephalus, raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and infarcts.
  • CSF Findings:
    • Lymphocytic predominance.
    • Elevated protein levels.
    • Low glucose levels.
    • Cobweb-like pellicle formation.

Diagnosis:

  • Gold Standard: CSF culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Supportive Tests: Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) stain, PCR for tuberculosis, or CSF ADA levels.

Management:

  • Initiation of antitubercular therapy (ATT).
  • Steroids to reduce inflammation.

Chemical meningitis (Option D): This occurs due to the rupture of tumor contents (e.g., from a dermoid cyst or glioma) into the CSF.

CSF Findings: Variable inflammatory response, often with elevated proteins but no infective organisms.

Reference:

NCBI Article on Meningitis

PubMed Article

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents with sudden-onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray reveals findings consistent with pulmonary edema. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema (ACPE).

Precipitating factors:

  • Severe hypertension
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Chronic heart failure exacerbation
  • Medication non-compliance
  • Excessive salt intake

Symptoms:

  • Sudden severe dyspnea
  • Pink frothy sputum
  • Cyanosis
  • Rales and rhonchi heard on auscultation

Chest X-ray findings:

  • Interstitial edema
  • Alveolar edema in a butterfly pattern
  • Possible cardiomegaly

Management of Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema:

  1. IV Nitroglycerin
    • Mechanism: Reduces preload and afterload by causing venodilation, lowering pulmonary venous pressure.
    • Indication: Rapid relief of pulmonary edema symptoms without causing hypotension.
    • Administration: Start with sublingual nitroglycerin; escalate to intravenous if symptoms persist.
  2. Oxygen Therapy: Maintain oxygen saturation >92%. Use non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) or intubation if oxygenation fails.
  3. Diuretics (e.g., Furosemide): Used to remove excess fluid but only after stabilizing the patient's hemodynamics.
  4. Morphine: Provides venodilation and reduces anxiety, but use is controversial due to the risk of respiratory depression.
  5. Positioning: Sitting upright with legs dependent to reduce venous return in patients without hypotension.

Intravenous salbutamol (Option A): Salbutamol is a β2-agonist used for acute severe asthma or hyperkalemia, not pulmonary edema.

Nebulization with salbutamol (Option C): Similar to Option A, it is used in asthma management, not for ACPE.

Oxygen and antibiotics (Option D): Oxygen therapy is indicated, but antibiotics are not used in cardiogenic pulmonary edema unless there is an underlying infection like pneumonia.

Reference:

AHA Journals

PubMed Article

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is undergoing tooth extraction for dental caries. Which of the following does not require prophylaxis against infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a congenital heart defect; however, it is generally not considered a high-risk condition for infective endocarditis unless there are other complicating factors, such as a significant shunt or right-sided heart failure.

Infective Endocarditis (IE)

Infective endocarditis (IE) is a bacterial or fungal infection of the endocardial surface of the heart, typically affecting the heart valves.

Prophylaxis against infective endocarditis is recommended before certain invasive procedures (like dental extractions) for patients at high risk of developing this condition.

Indications for Prophylaxis in Infective Endocarditis:

High-Risk Patients:

  • Prosthetic heart valves (mechanical/bioprosthetic) (Option D)
  • History of infective endocarditis (Option A)
  • Congenital heart disease (CHD):
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD (Option C)
    • Repaired CHD with prosthetic material (first 6 months)
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with valvulopathy

Procedures Requiring Prophylaxis:

  • Dental: Extractions, periodontal surgery, root canal, dental implants
  • Respiratory: Tonsillectomy, adenoidectomy, bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • GI/GU: Endoscopy with biopsy, colonoscopy, cystoscopy (high-risk patients)

Prophylaxis Regimen:

  • Amoxicillin: 2 grams orally, 30-60 minutes before
  • Alternative (Penicillin allergic):
    • Clindamycin: 600 mg orally
    • Azithromycin: 500 mg orally

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the jugular venous pressure (JVP) finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests atrial fibrillation (AF), a common arrhythmia with an irregularly irregular heartbeat, often accompanied by a fast heart rate (e.g., 120 beats/min). The pulse deficit of 20 indicates that not every atrial contraction is passed to the ventricles due to irregular conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node, meaning some atrial beats are not followed by ventricular contractions.



Management option for AF as per CHA2DS2-VASc score

  • 0: need not anticoagulate
  • 1: Give aspirin
  • >=2: Warfarin/Dabigatran/Rivaroxaban

Absent p wave (Option A): This is a characteristic ECG finding in atrial fibrillation. The absence of the P wave on ECG signifies that there is no organized atrial contraction, which leads to the irregularly irregular ventricular rhythm.

Cannon a wave (Option C): Cannon a waves occur in atrioventricular (AV) dissociation, where the atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve, leading to a large, prominent a wave.

Raised JVP with normal waveform (Option D): A raised JVP with a normal waveform is typically seen in conditions like congestive heart failure, right ventricular infarction, or superior vena cava obstruction. In atrial fibrillation, the JVP may be raised, but the waveform will not be normal.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34506629/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3221309/

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. The absolute eosinophil count is >5000/µL. Chest x-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The nocturnal cough, fever, breathlessness, and wheezing with eosinophilia of >5000/µL and miliary pattern in chest X-ray all point to the diagnosis of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE)

TPE is a pulmonary hyperreactive condition triggered by trapped microfilariae in lung tissue, leading to symptoms like nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing.

Pathophysiology:

  • Eosinophils are key in the pathogenesis, triggered by microfilariae released from the lymphatic system that become trapped in pulmonary microcirculation.
  • Eosinophils degranulate, releasing proteins to clear microfilariae and cause lung damage.
  • IL-4 promotes airway hyperactivity, while IFN-gamma suppresses it.
  • An overactive TH2 response increases IL-4, IL-5, and specific IgG, IgM, and IgE antibodies, leading to eosinophilia.

Clinical features:

  • History of travel or residence in filarial endemic areas.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dry, paroxysmal, nocturnal cough
    • Dyspnea
    • Systemic signs (fever, malaise, weight loss)
    • Peripheral eosinophilia (>3,000/mm³)
    • Extrapulmonary signs: Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Physical Findings: Wheezing, crepitations, organomegaly, enlarged lymph nodes.

Investigations:

  • Blood Tests: Leukocytosis with eosinophilia, elevated IgE, filarial antibody titers.
  • Stool Test: Rule out other parasitic causes.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest X-ray: Reticulonodular opacities, miliary mottling, or normal in 20-30% of cases.
    • Chest CT: Bronchiectasis, lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion in unclear cases.
  • Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs): Mixed restrictive and mild to moderate obstructive patterns.

Management:

  • First-line:
    • Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for 21 days.
    • It targets both microfilariae and adults, leading to dramatic symptom improvement.
  • Adjunctive:
    • Corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation, particularly in chronic cases.
  • Alternative Drugs:
    • Ivermectin and albendazole target microfilariae and adult worms, though there is limited data.

Bronchial asthma (Option A) is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to symptoms such as wheezing, coughing (often nocturnal), breathlessness, and occasionally fever. However, the presence of a miliary pattern on chest X-ray is not typical of bronchial asthma.

Miliary tuberculosis (Option B) is a severe form of tuberculosis (TB) in which the infection spreads throughout the body, including the lungs. It is characterized by the dissemination of tiny, millimetre-sized lesions throughout various organs, including the lungs, giving a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. The elevated absolute eosinophil count is not typical of miliary tuberculosis.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) (Option D), also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis, is an immune-mediated lung disease caused by the inhalation of various organic substances such as dust, moulds, or animal proteins. The absolute eosinophil count can be elevated in some cases. However, the presence of a miliary pattern on chest X-ray is not typical of HP.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557524/

choices.text: Increase the dose of beta blocker

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent retrosternal chest pain, with each episode lasting for 3-5 min and subsiding with sublingual nitrate. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-wave. He is a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia and is currently on aspirin, atenolol, metformin, and lovastatin. His serum troponin I level is elevated. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation, history of recurrent chest pain, and ECG findings of left ventricular hypertrophy ,flat T-waves and elevated troponin I levels raise concerns for NSTEMI-acute coronary syndrome.

Management of NSTEMI-ACS

Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.


IV glyceryl trinitrate infusion (Option A) is given in case of patients presenting with ongoing chest pain. The given scenario here gives a history of recurrent chest pains but does not specify that the patient suffers from it at presentation. Hence, it is not the best step for management.

Add clopidogrel (Option C): Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug that has antithrombotic action, however, enoxaparin is a better agent than clopidogrel and hence not preferred.

Increase the dose of beta-blocker (Option D): This step is not preferred over anticoagulation therapy using enoxparin.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK442000/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9790281/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557814/

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/kg, and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The serum osmolality is low (270 mOsm/kg, below the normal 285-295 mOsm/kg), indicating a diluted serum, while the high urine osmolality (1000 mOsm/kg) shows that the kidneys are still concentrating urine. This pattern is characteristic of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia, most commonly seen in SIADH, where inappropriate ADH secretion leads to water retention and dilution of serum sodium. This severe dilutional hyponatremia can lower sodium levels enough to trigger seizures.

Causes of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia include:

  • Drugs (desmopressin, oxytocin, antidepressants, opioids, thiazide diuretics, carbamazepine or its analogues, vincristine, nicotine, antipsychotics, chlorpropamide, cyclophosphamide, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, MDMA)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)
    • Increased ADH leads to water retention with near-normal sodium levels.
    • Water overload leads to the release of ANP ( Atrial natriuretic peptide) from atria.
    • ANP causes natriuresis which leads to euvolemic hyponatremia.
    • No edema occurs.
    • Causes of SIADH:
      • Tumours
      • Central nervous system disorders: stroke, trauma, infection, psychosis, porphyria
      • Pulmonary disorders: pneumonia, tuberculosis, obstructive lung disease
      • Drugs: anticonvulsants, psychotropics, antidepressants, cytotoxics, oral hypoglycaemic agents, opiates
      • Idiopathic
  • Addison's disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • High fluid intake in conditions like primary polydipsia or potomania, caused by a low intake of solutes with relatively high fluid intake
  • Medical testing related to excessive fluids, such as a colonoscopy or cardiac catheterisation
  • Iatrogenic

Plasma osmolality in hypernatremia (Option A) would typically be associated with increased serum osmolality (>295 mOsm/kg) due to a deficit of water in relation to sodium.

Hyperkalemia (Option C) refers to an elevated level of potassium in the blood. It is not related to the given scenario as it occurs in conditions of metabolic acidosis, particularly in kidney disease, where potassium excretion is impaired.

Hypokalemia (Option D) is a condition characterized by a low level of potassium in the blood. It is caused by diuretics, GI losses, and hyperaldosteronism.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470386/#:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470386/#:

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with laboured breathing. ECG shows tall, tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The low pH and HCO3 levels in the blood show metabolic acidosis consistent with chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia.


pH-7.14, pCO₂-20 mmHg, HCO₃- 34 mEq/L (Option B): Although the pH and pCO₂ suggest acidemia with respiratory compensation, the high HCO₃ (34 mEq/L) is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis. A high bicarbonate would be seen in metabolic alkalosis, which does not fit this clinical picture.

pH-7.54, HCO₃- 27 mEq/L, pCO₂- 34 mmHg (Option C): This option shows a high pH (7.54), indicating alkalosis. The pCO₂ is slightly low, suggesting respiratory alkalosis, while the HCO₃ is near normal. This acid-base picture does not match the metabolic acidosis expected in a dialysis patient with hyperkalemia.

pH-7.4, HCO₃- 27 mEq/L, pCO₂- 40 mmHg (Option D): This combination of normal pH, normal pCO₂, and normal HCO₃- does not indicate any significant acid-base imbalance. Therefore, this option is less likely to be the correct acid-base imbalance in this case.

questions.text: What is the child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dl, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR =2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites?
questions.solution:
This patient belongs to Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class B based on the following scoring:

  • Serum Bilirubin: 2.5 mg/dL (2 points)
  • Serum Albumin: 3 g/dL (2 points)
  • Prothrombin Time (INR): 5 seconds (INR = 2) (2 points)
  • Encephalopathy: None (1 point)
  • Ascites: Mild (2 points)

The total score is 9 points, which places the patient in Child-Pugh Class B.

Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score:

  • Employed to assess the severity of liver disease, predict prognosis for liver cirrhosis, and determine a patient's eligibility for liver transplantation, using a scoring system that incorporates parameters such as:
    • Bilirubin
    • INR
    • Albumin
    • Ascites
    • Hepatic encephalopathy

  • The Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score is determined by summing the scores for each parameter.
    • Category A: 5-6 (Compensated cirrhosis)
    • Category B: 7-9 (Decompensated cirrhosis)
    • Category C: > 10 (Severely decompensated cirrhosis)

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse is seen in Aortic regurgitation.


Aortic stenosis (Option A): Severe aortic stenosis is associated with pulsus parvus et tardus, characterized by a carotid pulse that rises slowly and peaks late due to restricted blood flow through the narrowed valve, which is distinct from the bounding water hammer pulse seen in aortic regurgitation.

Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation (Option C): In cases where aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation coexist, the stenosis reduces the stroke volume ejected into the aorta, limiting the high-amplitude and rapid upstroke typical of a water hammer pulse seen in isolated aortic regurgitation.

Mitral regurgitation (Option D): Chronic mitral regurgitation shows a sharp, low-volume pulse due to reduced forward cardiac output, while acute mitral regurgitation may present with a narrow pulse pressure. Neither scenario produces the rapid upstroke and collapse characteristic of a water hammer pulse.

choices.text: Single positive blood culture for HACEK group is a major criterion
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is a major criterion
Documentation of four minor criteria allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke's criteria?
questions.solution:
A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is a major criterion in the modified Duke's criteria for infective endocarditis.


A single positive blood culture for HACEK group (Option A) organisms (Haemophilus species, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella) is not considered a major criterion in the modified Duke's criteria.

Complete dehiscence of a prosthetic valve (Option C) is not a criterion in the modified Duke's criteria.

A definitive diagnosis of endocarditis can be made in patients with two major criteria, one major and three minor criteria, or five minor (Option D) criteria.

questions.text: Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) causes
questions.solution:
Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) leads to lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This is a condition caused by ischemia in the lateral medulla oblongata, which affects several neural structures.

Features of Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallenberg Syndrome):

  • Cerebellar Symptoms: Vertigo, ataxia, and nystagmus due to involvement of the vestibular nucleus.
  • Sensory Deficits: Loss of pain and temperature sensation on the contralateral body (spinothalamic tract) and ipsilateral face (trigeminal nerve).
  • Dysphagia and Hoarseness: Due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus, affecting the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.
  • Horner's Syndrome: Ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the ipsilateral side due to sympathetic pathway disruption.

PICA, a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies blood to the cerebellum and parts of the brainstem. When thrombosis occurs, it disrupts blood flow to the lateral medulla, leading to the characteristic features of the lateral medullary syndrome.

choices.text: ECHO showing diastolic collapse of RA and RV walls during inspiration

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient presents with chest pain and breathlessness. She had a brief viral illness 1 week ago. Her chest X-ray is given below. What is not true about this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has pericardial effusion, suggested by the history of viral illness, chest pain, breathlessness, and the "water bottle" sign on the chest X-ray. The signs and symptoms align with a diagnosis of pericardial effusion, which can progress to cardiac tamponade.

In pericardial effusion, heart sounds, including S1, are typically muffled or faint due to the insulating effect of the fluid surrounding the heart. A loud S1 is not a feature of this condition.

Pericardial Effusion

Symptoms:

  • Chest pain: Often pleuritic in nature.
  • Breathlessness: Due to impaired cardiac output.
  • Fatigue: Resulting from reduced myocardial function.

Physical Signs:

Beck's triad includes:

  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Hypotension
  • Distended neck veins (jugular venous distention)

Pulsus paradoxus: An exaggerated drop in blood pressure (>10 mmHg) during inspiration, indicating tamponade. (Option B ruled out)

Imaging and ECG Findings:

Electrical alternans (ECG finding): It is characterized by beat-to-beat variation in the amplitude of QRS complexes.


Chest X-ray: Water bottle sign: Enlarged cardiac silhouette due to pericardial effusion.


Echocardiography: Shows fluid accumulation with possible diastolic collapse of the right atrium (RA) and right ventricle (RV) in the setting of tamponade. (Option D ruled out)


Management:

Mild effusions: Monitoring and treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., infection, inflammation, malignancy).

Significant effusions or tamponade:

  • Emergency pericardiocentesis: To drain the accumulated fluid and relieve pressure on the heart. (Option C ruled out)
  • Surgical drainage: In cases where pericardiocentesis is not effective or if the effusion recurs.

questions.text: A patient presents with chest pain for 1 hour, perspiration, and anxiety. The ECG shows ST depressions in leads V2 and V3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation, along with ECG findings of ST depressions in leads V2 and V3, suggests posterior wall myocardial infarction (MI).

Clinical Presentation: Chest pain, sweating, and anxiety are classic symptoms of acute myocardial infarction.

ECG Changes in Posterior Wall MI:

  • ST depressions in anterior leads (V1-V3) are reciprocal changes caused by ischemia in the posterior wall of the heart.
  • A true ST elevation might be observed in posterior leads (V7-V9), which are not part of a standard 12-lead ECG.

NSTEMI (Option A): NSTEMI may present with ST depression, but it typically involves multiple leads without a focal reciprocal pattern specific to V2 and V3.

Unstable Angina (Option B): Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain at rest or with minimal exertion. While it may show ST depression.

Acute Myocarditis (Option D): Myocarditis often presents with diffuse ST elevation or PR depression, indicative of widespread myocardial inflammation.

Reference: https://www.cardiologymedjournal.com/articles/jccm-aid1082.php

choices.text: Acyclovir, eye patching and eye ointment

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset lower motor neuron facial paralysis on his left side. Radiological tests showed no deficits. What is the next best step in the management?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests Bell's palsy, a condition characterized by sudden onset lower motor neuron facial paralysis. It typically involves unilateral facial weakness, which can affect both the upper and lower parts of the face. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning that other potential causes of facial paralysis must be ruled out first.


Intravenous antibiotics, and mastoidectomy (Option A): This is typically used for acute otitis media or mastoiditis, not for Bell’s palsy. The absence of deficits on the radiological tests rules out significant infections like mastoiditis.

Electrical stimulation of facial nerve (Option C): Electrical stimulation is not a recommended primary treatment for Bell's palsy. It has shown limited benefit in recovery and is not part of the standard management protocol.

Facial nerve decompression (Option D): Facial nerve decompression is typically indicated in cases of severe facial nerve compression (e.g., from a tumor or trauma), but not for Bell's palsy. It is not recommended in the routine treatment of this condition, as most patients recover spontaneously.

questions.text: A patient with a history of sore throat was treated with antibiotics. He now presents with facial swelling. Urine examination shows eosinophilia and WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation and history strongly point to acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) as the most likely diagnosis.

Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN) is a condition characterized by inflammation of the renal interstitium, often caused by an allergic reaction or an immune-mediated response. It can result in renal dysfunction, typically presenting with acute kidney injury (AKI).

Causes:

  • Medications: The most common cause of AIN is drug-induced, with antibiotics (like penicillins, cephalosporins), NSAIDs, and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) being the usual culprits.
  • Infections: Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections
  • Systemic Diseases: Conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or sarcoidosis.

Symptoms:

  • Fever, rash, and eosinophilia are often seen.
  • Acute kidney injury with oliguria or anuria may develop.
  • Fluid retention due to impaired renal function, resulting facial edema
  • Flank pain and hematuria are possible.

Diagnosis:

  • Urinalysis: Shows pyuria (WBC casts) and possibly eosinophils.
  • Blood tests: Elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels.
  • Kidney biopsy: Can confirm AIN with characteristic histopathological changes like infiltration of lymphocytes and eosinophils in the renal interstitium.

Treatment:

  • Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step.
  • Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases to reduce inflammation.

Lupus Nephritis (Option B):

  • Lupus nephritis typically presents in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Clinical signs include joint pain, malar rash, and high levels of antinuclear antibodies (ANA), which are not described in this case.

Pyelonephritis (Option C):

  • Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever, flank pain, dysuria, and bacteriuria.
  • WBC casts may be present, but eosinophilia is not a feature.

Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) (Option D): PSGN occurs after a streptococcal throat or skin infection, often with cola-colored urine, proteinuria, and red blood cell (RBC) casts.

Reference:

https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/243597-treatment#d10

choices.text: Rise of creatinine by more than 10% is suggestive of acute rejection.
Rise of creatinine by more than 5% is suggestive of acute rejection.
Serum creatinine does not rise in acute renal allograft rejection.
Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection.

questions.text: A patient has undergone an acute renal allograft transplantation. What would indicate its rejection?
questions.solution:
After renal allograft transplantation, serum creatinine is one of the earliest and most sensitive indicators of graft dysfunction. A rise in serum creatinine, even if small or unexplained, necessitates further investigation to rule out acute rejection.

Acute Renal Allograft Rejection

Acute renal allograft rejection occurs when the recipient's immune system identifies the transplanted kidney as foreign, leading to cellular or antibody-mediated immune responses that cause kidney inflammation and damage.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Typically occurs weeks to months post-transplant, but can occur later if immunosuppression is reduced.
  • Symptoms may include reduced urine output, graft tenderness, fever, and malaise, though not always present.
  • Any unexplained increase in creatinine should raise suspicion for acute rejection.

Types of Acute Rejection:

  • Cellular Rejection (T-cell Mediated): T-cells attack the graft, causing inflammation and tissue damage.
  • Antibody-Mediated Rejection (AMR): Antibodies attack the donor endothelial cells, leading to endothelial injury and microvascular thrombosis.

Confirmatory Investigation:

  • Renal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing acute rejection and determining the type of rejection.
  • Biopsy findings:
    • Cellular rejection: T-cell infiltration and inflammation.
    • AMR: Endothelial damage and microvascular inflammation.

Treatment:

  • Cellular rejection: Treated with increased immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., steroids, ATG).
  • AMR: Requires treatments like plasmapheresis, IVIG, or rituximab.

questions.text: A stroke patient presents with an inability to identify objects but can determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects. Which of the following lobes is involved?
questions.solution:
The inability to identify objects and the ability to determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects refer to visual agnosia, which is caused by lesions involving the temporal lobe.


Lesions in a patient's frontal lobe (Option A) can lead to certain symptoms such as trouble with learning, deficits in visual-motor function, executive dysfunction and problems with attention (planning, focusing, and inhibition).

Parietal lobe (Option B): Right - Damage to this area can cause visuospatial deficits (e.g., the patient may have difficulty finding their way around new, or even familiar, places).Parietal Lobe, Left: Damage to this area may disrupt a person's ability to understand spoken and/or written language.

Unilateral occipital lobe (Option D) lesion causes contralateral homonymous hemianopia. It is a visual field defect on the same side of both eyes contralateral to the site of the lesion - lesions of the occipital lobe due to the posterior cerebral artery infarct cause homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK493156/

questions.text: Match the following?
questions.solution:
The correct match is:


Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559166/

https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/sickle-cell-disease/symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is recently approved to be used in patients with heart failure with low ejection fraction and reduced urine output?
questions.solution:
Anti-diabetic drugs reducing cardiovascular mortality are SGLT2 inhibitors (Empagliflozin, Dapagliflozin) and GLP1 agonists (Semaglutide, Dulaglutide).


Linagliptin (Option A): It is a DPP-4 inhibitor. The DPP 4 enzyme is responsible for the breakdown of incretins such as GLP-1.

Pioglitazone (Option C): These drugs have been shown to cause dose-dependent fluid retention, hence this drug class is generally avoided in patients with heart failure.

Degludec (Option D): Insulin degludec is a long-acting insulin used to treat hyperglycemia caused by type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus.

choices.text: Infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg dose insulin after 1 hour of IVF
0.1 Unit/kg insulin stat followed infusion of 0.5 U- 0.1 U/kg dose insulin and IVF
0.1 U/kg insulin subcutaneous stat followed by IVF
IVF followed by subcutaneous 0.1 U/kg insulin

questions.text:
A child is brought to the ER in an unconscious state after severe vomiting and abdominal pain episodes. HR = 100/min and BP=100/60 mm Hg.
Work up shows:
pH=7.2
Blood glucose 300 mg/dl
Ketone 3+.
What should be the best management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario here points to the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis.The child has moderate dehydration (vomiting, hypotension), so fluid resuscitation is started first, followed by insulin infusion after 1 hour to safely manage DKA



Contraindication of Insulin Drip:

  • Insulin should be withheld if the serum potassium level is below 3.3 mmol/L.
  • The target is to maintain serum potassium levels above 3.5 mmol/L (3.5 meq/L) to start the insulin drip.
  • Hypokalemia can lead to diaphragmatic paralysis and potentially result in respiratory arrest.

Reference:

  1. Initial Potassium Replacement in Diabetic Ketoacidosis
  2. Hypokalemic paralysis in a professional bodybuilder - PubMed
  3. Management of adult diabetic ketoacidosis - PMC
  4. Comparing the clinical effects of balanced electrolyte solutions versus normal saline in managing diabetic ketoacidosis
  5. Adult Diabetic Ketoacidosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial treatment of choice for managing the condition in a female patient who comes to the hospital with palpitations, having stable vital signs and an ECG showing the following?
questions.solution:
Adenosine is the first-line management of the presented condition. The ECG pattern shown suggests Paroxysmal SupraVentricular Tachycardia (PSVT), a common arrhythmia characterized by rapid heart rates originating above the ventricles. Adenosine is a potent vasodilator and affects the electrical conduction system of the heart. It activates specific receptors in the heart, particularly the adenosine A1 receptors, which help to slow down the conduction through the AV node. This interruption of the abnormal electrical pathway in SVT can restore normal sinus rhythm.

Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT):

  1. Signs and Symptoms:
    • Sudden onset of rapid, regular palpitations
    • Dizziness or lightheadedness
    • Shortness of breath
    • Chest discomfort or pressure
    • Anxiety
    • Fatigue
    • In severe cases: syncope, hypotension, or heart failure symptoms
  2. ECG Findings:
    • Regular, narrow-complex tachycardia (QRS duration <120 ms)
    • Reduced R-R interval
    • Heart rate between 150-250 bpm
    • P waves often not visible or buried in T waves
    • Common types include:
      • a) AV Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT): Retrograde P waves may appear as pseudo R' in V1 or pseudo S in inferior leads
      • b) AV Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT): Retrograde P waves may be visible after the QRS complex
  3. Management:

Amiodarone (Option A) is used to treat Stable Monomorphic Ventricular tachycardia.

DC Cardioversion (Option C) is used to treat Atrial flutter, Atrial fibrillation

Primary PCI (Option D) is used to treat acute myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of Brown Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Brown-Séquard syndrome is a specific pattern of spinal cord injury characterized by a hemisection of the spinal cord (one-half of the spinal cord is damaged or severed).


Hemisection of the spinal cord (as shown in the image) results in I/L loss of Dorsal and Pyramidal column tracts and C/L loss of Spinothalamic tract (STT) 2 segments below the level of lesion is known as Brown-Sequard syndrome, as STT (specifically Lateral STT) relays at the dorsal root ganglion and crosses over at 1-2 segments above the level of that spinal cord.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's progressive bilateral limb weakness, muscle wasting, positive Babinski sign, absent deep tendon reflexes, and absence of sensory or autonomic dysfunction are consistent with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS):

  • ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease and a prime example of neurodegenerative disorders.
  • Genetic Causes:
    • Mutant Proteins: SOD1, ubiquilin-1/-2, and p62 mutations disrupt protein degradation.
    • RNA Processing: C9orf72, TDP43, and FUS mutations affect RNA transport/processing.
    • Axonal Transport: Mutations in dynactin and profilin-1 affect axonal transport.
  • Pathology:
    • The hallmark of ALS is the death of both lower motor neurons (anterior horn cells and brainstem motor neurons) and upper motor neurons (corticospinal neurons).
    • ALS involves both denervation and muscle atrophy, particularly in proximal muscles, and results in selective loss of motor neurons.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Lower Motor Neuron Dysfunction: Asymmetric muscle weakness, muscle cramping, fasciculations, muscle atrophy and bulbar palsy.
    • Upper Motor Neuron Dysfunction: Reflex hyperactivity, muscle stiffness, spasticity and pseudobulbar palsy.
    • Corticobulbar Projection Degeneration: Results in dysarthria (speech difficulty) and pseudobulbar affect (excessive weeping or laughing).
    • Symmetric Muscle Involvement: Over time, more muscle groups become involved, leading to a symmetric distribution of the disorder in all regions.
    • Preserved Sensory and Cognitive Functions: Sensory, bowel and bladder, and cognitive functions are preserved even in the late stages.
    • Ocular Motility Sparing: Ocular motility remains unaffected until the very late stages of ALS.
  • Treatment:
    • No treatment halts the underlying ALS pathology.
    • Riluzole: Reduces excitotoxicity via decreased glutamate release.
    • Edaravone: Acts as an antioxidant and it modestly reduces disability progression.
    • Phenylbutyrate and Taurursodiol: Oral combination shown to slow disease progression and extend survival by improving mitochondrial and endoplasmic reticulum function.

Multiple sclerosis (Option A) typically presents with relapsing-remitting episodes, optic neuritis, and a combination of upper motor neuron (UMN) and sensory deficits, which are absent in this case, and the patient lacks the characteristic visual and brainstem symptoms like ataxia and nystagmus.

Guillain-barre syndrome (Option C) causes rapidly progressive ascending paralysis with areflexia, sensory involvement, and autonomic dysfunction, which this patient does not exhibit, as the weakness is bilateral and progressive over a longer period without sensory loss.

Tropical spastic paraparesis (Option D) is associated with spastic paraparesis, sensory deficits, and bladder disturbances but no lower motor neuron (LMN) involvement, which contrasts with this patient's presentation of muscle wasting (suggestive of LMN involvement) and absence of bladder dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student with fever had developed epistaxis which had resolved on its own and on evaluation his platelet counts are 14,000/μL and BP is 110/70 mmHg and there is a 28% rise in haematocrit. Then he has been afebrile for the last 24 hours now, what should be the next steps of management of this patient?
1. Give 4 units of platelets
2. Give plenty of oral fluids
3. Give IV fluids
4. Keep under observation
5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution: The likely diagnosis in this patient considering the above given scenario, could be dengue. And the appropriate management of dengue patients at this stage would be plenty of oral fluids and IV fluids to ensure adequate hydration. In this patient, since his epistaxis resolved spontaneously and the hematocrit is improving, he needs to be kept as inpatient for observation.
